revisions:
[{'created': '2013-07-30 17:37:03.000000000', 'message': "Add boto tests for InstanceInitiatedShutdownBehavior=terminate

The EC2 API supports two different behaviors when an instance
shuts itself down -- 'stop' and 'terminate'.  This boto test
starts an instance of each and uses ssh to call shutdown inside
the instance, and then checks to see if the instance ends
up in 'stopped' state or if it's gone completely.

Fixes bug #1131395

Change-Id: Ia79083379f8161b77336cf595c90f1dbffbf7409
"}]
commit_message:
Add boto tests for InstanceInitiatedShutdownBehavior=terminate

The EC2 API supports two different behaviors when an instance
shuts itself down -- 'stop' and 'terminate'.  This boto test
starts an instance of each and uses ssh to call shutdown inside
the instance, and then checks to see if the instance ends
up in 'stopped' state or if it's gone completely.

Fixes bug #1131395

Change-Id: Ia79083379f8161b77336cf595c90f1dbffbf7409

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-08-26 01:51:38.000000000', 'message': "WIP Refactor ownership check during delete

This change refactors how the project_id and user_id are chosen during
a delete operation.  The two checks are refactored into two new helper
functions and duplicate code is replaced with said helpers.

Note: this has been future-proofed by using the openstack-common names
'tenant' and 'user' instead of the nova 'project_id' and 'user_id'.
I'd like to hear what others think about this.

Change-Id: Ia25c66a79b85890d09fb8f4aadc59b472fc7fbe6
"}, {'created': '2013-08-26 17:04:36.000000000', 'message': 'Refactor ownership check during instance delete

This change refactors the code that chooses the project_id and user_id
when nova compute deletes an instance.  The two checks for instance
ownership are refactored into two new helper functions in the nova
compute utils.  Duplicate code in the nova-compute api and manager
modules is removed.

Change-Id: Ia25c66a79b85890d09fb8f4aadc59b472fc7fbe6
'}, {'created': '2013-08-26 19:25:44.000000000', 'message': 'Refactor ownership check during instance delete

This change refactors the code that chooses the project_id and user_id
when nova compute deletes an instance.  The two checks for instance
ownership are refactored into two new helper functions in the nova
compute utils.  Duplicate code in the nova-compute api and manager
modules is removed.

Change-Id: Ia25c66a79b85890d09fb8f4aadc59b472fc7fbe6
'}]
commit_message:
Refactor ownership check during instance delete

This change refactors the code that chooses the project_id and user_id
when nova compute deletes an instance.  The two checks for instance
ownership are refactored into two new helper functions in the nova
compute utils.  Duplicate code in the nova-compute api and manager
modules is removed.

Change-Id: Ia25c66a79b85890d09fb8f4aadc59b472fc7fbe6

commit_message:
Enable rejoin_stack.sh to log screen output after unstack.sh

Change-Id: I2f7bb6ed3b5b021c1a742918b7686f3a2bda900e
Fixes: bug #1192568

subject: Fix secure delete for thick LVM snapshots

some of the details aside this seems MUCH better than what we have today and addresses a number of issues.  In the future if there are upstream tools available to make this even better then great, but for now I really appreciate he work Joe and Evan have done on this (and Eric in an earlier work as well).'}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2013-09-09 13:39:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: (3 inline comments)

I'm for this patch going in, but we need to make the commit msg summary more clear re: not fixing Thin LVM."}, {'account_id': 1420, 'date': '2013-09-09 22:15:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Hit this bug today and am testing the corresponding grizzly patch (realize this is the master review, but figured I'd weigh in here before anything gets committed)  Applying this fix appears to get snapshot deletion further along, but cinder is now failing to lvremove the snapshot, which is deadlocking LVM and blocking any later calls to LVM. http://paste.ubuntu.com/6085414/"}, {'account_id': 1082, 'date': '2013-09-10 00:17:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This seems like a hack.
There are 2 issues I see, both surrounding use of '-cow'.
a.) is there any guarantee or documentation that '-cow' is promised to be the device that backs the volume?  It would appear that if your assumption is wrong, and there is no '-cow' file in /dev, you will create a file in /dev/ (usually a tmpfs) of multiple GB in size.

b.) If this *is* documented, it surely seems like you're still operating behind the back of lvm, and adam's paste at http://paste.ubuntu.com/6085702/ shows there is possible fallout.

If there isn't a way to request lvm to wipe its cow devices, then it seems that the right fix is inside lvm."}, {'account_id': 1082, 'date': '2013-09-10 00:29:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: No score

I'll revoke some of my objections as it seems that at least people are looking at the right fix in lvm itself at https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=975052#c11 .

And '-cow' is at least documented (http://www.centos.org/docs/5/html/5.2/Cluster_Logical_Volume_Manager/snapshot-map.html)"}, {'account_id': 1420, 'date': '2013-09-10 01:21:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Do we know that side-stepping LVM and zero'ing out the -cow device is even sane?  Upstream's comments in the linked bugzilla make it sound like it currently is not:

"Other LVM options would take longer to code, such as modifying lvremove and/or lvconvert to detach the snapshot "cow" volume, leaving it as a normal LV for you to wipe and remove."'}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2013-09-10 01:48:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Adam: that quote is taken from a bug discussing adding LVM capabilities to do that for us, I believe, which is not (directly) related to this patch.  (FWIW that bugzilla shouldn't really be linked from this patch/bug.)"}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-09-10 03:43:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: No score

Adam,

So funny enough, I think you're running in to: https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1023755 which is what caused this whole mess to begin with.

I'll take another look tomorrow, but to be clear as we can't even get an existing bug fix in LVM I'm certainly not willing to punt in hopes of getting a new LVM feature implemented.

Perhaps I can ping one of the LVM maintainers for suggestions.

John"}, {'account_id': 1420, 'date': '2013-09-10 16:31:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

@Eric-  I was quoting Alasdair here because it sounds as if writing anything (zeros or other) to a a snapshots's -cow device would require some modification to LVM.  I can't seem to find any precedence elsewhere for doing the kind of backdoor zero'ing proposed here.  I'm wondering if whats being proposed is supported on the LVM side or if its trashing some internal LVM state that is leading to the strange behaviour I'm seeing.

@John- The dd'ing of the device is working as fine at expected speeds.  Its the later lvremove that is now appears to be causing racing udev events and a deadlock in LVM.  As I said, not certain this is related to dd'ing of the -cow device.  It may be an unrelated kernel/udev/Ubuntu-specific bug. Gonna revert this and https://review.openstack.org/#/c/20124/ to confirm (snapshots tests were working fine prior to this)"}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-09-12 05:16:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I'd like to move forward with this, based on input from LVM maintainers and testing against precise and fedora 17 I have not had any problems with this.

I'm sure there's a good chance we'll revisit this in the not so distant future, but this adresses the bug, doesn't have the hang issues we've had going to /dev/snapshot directly.

I know Adam was doing some testing on saucy so I'll hold up a bit, and I also know Eric is reconsidering the over-provision snapshot size method.  I'll check in with folks again tomorrow but I think we should move forward with this."}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2013-09-12 11:51:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I still think the commit message summary needs to be changed to "Fix secure delete for thick LVM snapshots" or similar.'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-09-12 17:45:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Hey Joe,
Folks doing a bit more testing, but in the meantime can you address the issues Eric pointed out WRT the commit message?

Also, the Change-Id should be the last line in the message"}, {'account_id': 1420, 'date': '2013-09-12 22:40:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

This patch tests fine on Ubuntu 12.04. Was hitting some issues on Saucy 13.10, but they appear unrelated to this patch and are fixed with some recent updates in Debian unstable to the dm/lvm udev rules.'}, {'account_id': 1475, 'date': '2013-09-16 18:49:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-09-16 18:50:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

[{'created': '2013-09-04 20:32:10.000000000', 'message': 'Fix secure delete for LVM snapshots

This change modifies the behaviour of the secure delete for LVM snapshots
to wipe the underlying COW of the snapshot LV instead of the snapshot LV
itself.

This change is necessary because the snapshot LV does not contain exactly the
same number of writable blocks as the original LV.  The COW includes header
information per COW block that identifies the device as a COW device as well
as the source and destination blocks for the changed item.  The amount of
metadata contained in the COW is variable based on I/O performed on the
snapshot.

This does not change the behavior of secure deletes on normal LVs.

Change-Id: I20e02b6c20d5ac539b5b5469e665fc986180f2e9

commit_message:
Fix secure delete for thick LVM snapshots

This change modifies the behaviour of the secure delete for thick
LVM snapshots to wipe the underlying COW of the snapshot LV
instead of the snapshot LV itself.

This change is necessary because the snapshot LV does not contain
exactly the same number of writable blocks as the original LV.  The
COW includes header information per COW block that identifies the
device as a COW device as well as the source and destination blocks
for the changed item.  The amount of metadata contained in the COW is
variable based on I/O performed on the snapshot.

This does not change the behavior of secure deletes on thin LVs
or secure deletes on the thick LV snapshot origin.

Closes-Bug: #1191812
Change-Id: I20e02b6c20d5ac539b5b5469e665fc986180f2e9

Fix a tiny mistake in api doc

GET /v2/meters/{meter_id} will return a list of samples that
limited to the specific meter.

Change-Id: I753a68b99d9ac253186689c73975e450cf335f3c
Fixes: Bug #1226524

commit_message:
Update requirements not to boto 2.13.0

Latest boto 2.13.0 has a bug which lead to unit tests fails, before
it's fixed avoid use this version.

Fix bug #1224832

Conflicts:
        requirements.txt

Change-Id: I8a81adfc0cb0ad37d27b11db3c881735a099a95c

* remove xml template serializer, because default serializer is enough

'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2013-09-05 22:24:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 6983, 'date': '2013-09-06 02:09:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-09-06 15:35:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I don't see anything that decodes the encoded string.

Does this mean that some code will be expecting Unicode strings and some code will be expecting utf-8 strings?"}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-09-06 15:47:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hmm, I have to claim ignorance here, I guess. I thought that safe_encode() would return a unicode string when called like that, although I guess it doesn't:

  >>> "foo".encode('utf-8')
  'foo'

I was going based on the technique used in the incomplete first attempt at this fix:

Id26f23ad7f975a3a50750927adbedb86bf80871d

Can you offer some advice?'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-09-06 16:00:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

The whole point of safe_encode() is to never return a unicode type. It always returns a str type encoded in utf-8.

Ultimately we want to keep all strings as the unicode type internally to Nova. Keeping a string encoded as a str type will lead to lots of confusion of what encoding it is, when it is encoded, etc.

If the transport needs an encoded str type (as opposed to a unicode type), then we should strive to make this as transparent as possible.

It looks to me right now that the sending side will see a unicode type but then the receiving side will see a str type encoded with utf-8. This is because the string appears to only ever be encoded but never decoded back to a unicode type.

Here's a good reference on why we should strive to use a unicode type internally as much as possible:
http://nedbatchelder.com/text/unipain.html

Your patch is a net improvement over the previous change since it fixes up the versioning issues and makes sure all other uses also get encoded, but the fact there is no decoding will likely lead to problems."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-09-06 16:05:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Okay, so I think the right thing to do is have a helper that keeps it unicode if it's unicode already, and if not, attempts to decode the string to a unicode, so that we're always storing unicode strings in the object. Does that sound right?

Something like:

  try:
      val = unicode(val)
  except UnicodeDecodeError:
      val = str.decode(val, 'utf-8')

?

In that case, I wonder if it's worth reverting the original (incorrect anyway) patch and just fixing it in this one."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-09-06 16:16:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Heh, actually, I suppose that's strutils.safe_decode() huh?"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-09-06 16:53:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Yeah, it looks like strutils.safe_decode() is good to use here.

This all assumes that we need to encode at all. The original bug was caused by using str(), which will fail with unicode types that has non-ascii characters.

The object code only "dehydrates" to a set of standard python types. Something else is serializing dicts, lists, etc when it hits the wire. That code could possibly also handle unicode types just fine. If that's the case, we don't need to do any encoding, we just need to call unicode() instead of str().

If that's not the case, then there are other pieces of code that aren't unicode safe either, like list_of_strings_or_none() and dict_of_strings_or_none().

Neither of those does any encoding of unicode types.'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-09-06 16:54:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Yeah, my read on it is to use safe_decode() and you're good."}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-09-06 16:54:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Forgot to vote :)"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-09-06 17:36:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Just to clarify since there appears to be some confusion.

We *really* want to keep everything as a unicode type.

When we receive an encoded str type, we should decode it to a unicode type as quickly as possible.

When we need to encode to a str type, we should do it as late as possible.

There's two solutions I see to this bug:
1) If the transport layer can handle unicode types, then we change str_or_none() to call unicode() instead of str() (or just not do anything if it's already a unicode type).
2) If the transport layer can't handle unicode types, then we make str_or_none() (and other similar places in this code) encode while dehydrating using strutils.safe_encode(). Then use strutils.safe_decode() while dehydrating.

This should make it transparent for the rest of the code.

Looking at the RPC code, it uses jsonutils, which *is* unicode safe:

    >>> jsonutils.dumps(u'\u2022')
    '"\\u2022"'

So it looks like the fix here is simply to call unicode() in str_or_none() instead of calling str(). (And maybe clean up the function names?)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-09-06 17:40:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-09-06 17:44:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Yeah, I was confused about what netted us a unicode and not. I think the latest version is what we want, which should be keeping unicode internally to the object, decoding from utf-8 if necessary.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-09-06 17:50:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

I don't understand the need for the call to safe_decode(). See my comment."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-09-06 18:09:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

So, I think the feedback I gained from the discussion is:

1. Don't care about decoding, just coerce to unicode and fail if that fails
2. Keep the auto-string-conversion (but to unicode) for now

I added a test which I think reflects the above. Also, I left the utility function for non-uuid strings, so that we can ensure that we're given a basestring later if we want to eliminate #2.

commit_message:
Fix non-unicode string values on objects

Originally, all of the objects used str() to specify string type
attributes. This prevents the use of unicode values. A previous
patch errantly updated the utility function without bumping all
of the affected objects' versions. This does that, and also
fixes the issue for bare str() attributes.

Change-Id: Iad83589d399309b95c32813a1a660a12e571066b
Closes-bug: 1221346

commit_message:
Document DiskFile API, fix ref impl unit tests

Add sphinx documentation for the DiskFile pluggable backend API. We
also updated references to the other account and container backend
docs.

** We have removed the "upload_size" attribute of the DiskFileWriter,
   changing it to be a return value of the "write()" method instead
   (one step simpler API).

As part of documenting the interface, all of the attributes have had
underscores ("_") appended to define them as internal to the reference
implementation.

Change-Id: I7385e8cf5712f7e0a0d43615b7bac2bd428787d5
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-18 00:12:16.000000000', 'message': 'Fix secure delete for thick LVM snapshots

This change modifies the behaviour of the secure delete for thick
LVM snapshots to wipe the underlying COW of the snapshot LV
instead of the snapshot LV itself.

This change is necessary because the snapshot LV does not contain
exactly the same number of writable blocks as the original LV.  The
COW includes header information per COW block that identifies the
device as a COW device as well as the source and destination blocks
for the changed item.  The amount of metadata contained in the COW is
variable based on I/O performed on the snapshot.

This does not change the behavior of secure deletes on thin LVs
or secure deletes on the thick LV snapshot origin.

Conflicts:
	cinder/tests/api/contrib/test_admin_actions.py
	cinder/tests/test_volume.py
	cinder/volume/drivers/lvm.py

Closes-Bug: #1191812
Change-Id: I20e02b6c20d5ac539b5b5469e665fc986180f2e9
(cherry picked from commit f702fe7e30e4021895dac8e7ab243e5192f8182d)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix secure delete for thick LVM snapshots

This change modifies the behaviour of the secure delete for thick
LVM snapshots to wipe the underlying COW of the snapshot LV
instead of the snapshot LV itself.

This change is necessary because the snapshot LV does not contain
exactly the same number of writable blocks as the original LV.  The
COW includes header information per COW block that identifies the
device as a COW device as well as the source and destination blocks
for the changed item.  The amount of metadata contained in the COW is
variable based on I/O performed on the snapshot.

This does not change the behavior of secure deletes on thin LVs
or secure deletes on the thick LV snapshot origin.

Conflicts:
	cinder/tests/api/contrib/test_admin_actions.py
	cinder/tests/test_volume.py
	cinder/volume/drivers/lvm.py

Closes-Bug: #1191812
Change-Id: I20e02b6c20d5ac539b5b5469e665fc986180f2e9
(cherry picked from commit f702fe7e30e4021895dac8e7ab243e5192f8182d)

[{'created': '2013-09-16 08:17:00.000000000', 'message': 'Add extend_volume for Huawei driver

Add extend_volume for Huawei T and Dorado5100 drivers.
We should create a volume with the increased size before
extending the origin volume. we also need to remove the
added volumes and delete them before delete the extended
volume. So we define a global list self.extended_lun_dict
to store the added volumes for each extended volume.

fixes bug 1225901

Change-Id: I761db4e9f8d337d10e64e53c314cd7fe615090a7
'}]
commit_message:
Add extend_volume for Huawei driver

Add extend_volume for Huawei T and Dorado5100 drivers.
We should create a volume with the increased size before
extending the origin volume. we also need to remove the
added volumes and delete them before delete the extended
volume. So we define a global list self.extended_lun_dict
to store the added volumes for each extended volume.

fixes bug 1225901

Change-Id: I761db4e9f8d337d10e64e53c314cd7fe615090a7

[{'created': '2013-09-18 00:34:06.000000000', 'message': 'Fix path to update-grub.

Automated build environments may not have /usr/sbin in the path, so we
now explicitly call update-grub with an absolute path.

Change-Id: I1c5b89e551e62df2463200b1889cb2342498c7dd
'}, {'created': '2013-09-18 01:00:29.000000000', 'message': 'Move textmode forcer to vm element.

Changing the grub config makes no sense in a build not heading for a vm
and may fail because grub is removed from images not including the vm
element. Forcing textmode for those images would be better done in nova.

Change-Id: I1c5b89e551e62df2463200b1889cb2342498c7dd
'}]
commit_message:
Move textmode forcer to vm element.

Changing the grub config makes no sense in a build not heading for a vm
and may fail because grub is removed from images not including the vm
element. Forcing textmode for those images would be better done in nova.

Change-Id: I1c5b89e551e62df2463200b1889cb2342498c7dd

commit_message:
Validate OS::Nova::Server block_device_mapping property

Make sure either volume_id or snapshot_id exists but not both. Also this patch
ensures that a bootable volume is specified when image is not given.

Fixes bug #1215267

Change-Id: Ia51f6c7aec9c0b257318992ee58febc392ea3d84

commit_message:
Use strings for block device mapping info

Nova client receives colon separated strings for block device mapping info
instead of a list.

Fixes bug #1221693

Change-Id: I321001d406f620d5f8a21e0f28cf706579ad64ad

[{'created': '2013-09-17 23:03:04.000000000', 'message': "Remove restart of iscsi services.

These services are named differently on Fedora and were failing the
run of os-collect-config.  Removing them altogether because, there's
no good reason for them to be restarted for Ubuntu either.

Change-Id: Ie99fb0c0071f1569651b75d5a9c0cdf53d37c57c
"}]
commit_message:
Remove restart of iscsi services.

These services are named differently on Fedora and were failing the
run of os-collect-config.  Removing them altogether because, there's
no good reason for them to be restarted for Ubuntu either.

Change-Id: Ie99fb0c0071f1569651b75d5a9c0cdf53d37c57c

subject: Remove debug and verbose config from nova.conf
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-09-17 23:46:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- gate-noop http://logs.openstack.org/58/47058/1/check/gate-noop/c05f2ce : SUCCESS in 0s
'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-09-17 23:59:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Makes sense since these params are ignored if log_config is set:

 def setup(product_name):
     if CONF.log_config:
         _load_log_config(CONF.log_config)
     else:
         _setup_logging_from_conf()

 def _setup_logging_from_conf():
     ...
     if CONF.debug:
         log_root.setLevel(logging.DEBUG)
     elif CONF.verbose:
         log_root.setLevel(logging.INFO)
     else:
         log_root.setLevel(logging.WARNING)

and our logging.conf contains:

    [logger_root]
    level = WARNING

However, CONF.debug is used in one other place:

 def _check_for_lock():
     if not CONF.debug:
         return None

And I could see it being used more widely. Maybe just remove verbose=True ?

Also, what are we doing in logging.conf that we can't do with nova.conf options?"}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-09-18 00:12:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

logging.conf sets log levels for some dependencies (https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/etc/nova/logging_sample.conf) Although not sure why we can't just set log level for all dependencies to warning.  As for the debug vs verbose part, that sounds like a second bug.  In the mean time I will just drop the verbose option."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-09-18 00:19:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-09-18 00:19:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- gate-noop http://logs.openstack.org/58/47058/2/check/gate-noop/a9cf982 : SUCCESS in 0s
'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-09-18 00:19:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

New patchset patch-id matches previous patchset, but commit message has changed.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-09-18 00:23:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Summary is we don't want debug enabled by default - we want production defaults

Makes you wonder how we'd support enabling debugging in devtest.sh"}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2013-09-18 00:26:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 6449, 'date': '2013-09-18 00:27:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-17 23:46:43.000000000', 'message': 'Remove overridden logging params from nova.conf

Debug and verbose are overridden by the log_config parameter, since
these are overridden anyway no reason to keep them around as they can
only lead to confusion.

Change-Id: I003ea1a80efc3e9271015393feb7ef7413412331
'}, {'created': '2013-09-18 00:19:52.000000000', 'message': "Remove debug and verbose config from nova.conf

Verbose is overridden by the log_config parameter, since
this is overridden anyway no reason to keep it around as it can
only lead to confusion.

Debug is used to set the log level, although its overridden by
log_config as well, and is also used to turn on debug mode only checks.
Since we want the default values here to be for production we shouldn't
set debug=True here.

Change-Id: I003ea1a80efc3e9271015393feb7ef7413412331
"}]
commit_message:
Remove debug and verbose config from nova.conf

Verbose is overridden by the log_config parameter, since
this is overridden anyway no reason to keep it around as it can
only lead to confusion.

Debug is used to set the log level, although its overridden by
log_config as well, and is also used to turn on debug mode only checks.
Since we want the default values here to be for production we shouldn't
set debug=True here.

Change-Id: I003ea1a80efc3e9271015393feb7ef7413412331

[{'created': '2013-09-14 22:44:22.000000000', 'message': 'Don't need to init testr in run_tests.sh

In run_tests.sh, function init_testr will initialize testr if the
directory .testrepository is not existed. Actually, testr will do
the check before run the test:

In Python package testrepository,
setuptools_command.py:Testr.run

68 def run(self):
69 """Set up testr repo, then run testr"""
70     if not os.path.isdir(".testrepository"):
71         self._run_testr("init")

So, init_testr can be removed safely.

Change-Id: I51e73efe4e9b80bbf0159a5bce0db81fc049b9ce
'}, {'created': '2013-09-14 22:52:08.000000000', 'message': 'Don't need to init testr in run_tests.sh

In run_tests.sh, function init_testr will initialize testr if the
directory .testrepository is not existed. Actually, testr will do
the check before run the test:

In Python package testrepository,
setuptools_command.py:Testr.run

68 def run(self):
69 """Set up testr repo, then run testr"""
70     if not os.path.isdir(".testrepository"):
71         self._run_testr("init")

So, init_testr can be removed safely.

Fixes Bug #1222688
Change-Id: I51e73efe4e9b80bbf0159a5bce0db81fc049b9ce
'}]
commit_message:
Don't need to init testr in run_tests.sh

In run_tests.sh, function init_testr will initialize testr if the
directory .testrepository is not existed. Actually, testr will do
the check before run the test:

In Python package testrepository,
setuptools_command.py:Testr.run

68 def run(self):
69 """Set up testr repo, then run testr"""
70     if not os.path.isdir(".testrepository"):
71         self._run_testr("init")

So, init_testr can be removed safely.

Fixes Bug #1222688
Change-Id: I51e73efe4e9b80bbf0159a5bce0db81fc049b9ce

Remove underscore tests.init hack

This seems not needed anymore as tests pass without it, and it's not
Python 3 comptaible.

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-11 16:28:14.000000000', 'message': "Translate all substitution elements of a Message object

Some Messages are created with Message objects interpolated within a
Message. E.g.:

    msg = _('Message 1: %(msg_2)s') % {'msg_2': _('Message 2')}

The problem is that we were only translating the base Message but not
the Message substitutions within, thus in those cases Messages were only
being partially translated.

The fix sets the locale property for all Message substitution parameters
upon setting it on the base Message.

Fixes bug: #1221808

Change-Id: Ic3119df23a090cfaa160c1461e955f0af55fe1cf
"}, {'created': '2013-09-11 16:29:52.000000000', 'message': "Translate all substitution elements of a Message object

commit_message:
Translate all substitution elements of a Message object

Some Messages are created with further Message object substitutions.
E.g.:

    msg = _('Message 1: %(msg_2)s') % {'msg_2': _('Message 2')}

The problem is that we were only translating the base Message but not
the Message substitutions within, thus in those cases Messages were only
being partially translated.

The fix sets the locale property for all Message substitution parameters
upon setting it on the base Message.

Fixes bug: #1221808

Change-Id: Ic3119df23a090cfaa160c1461e955f0af55fe1cf

commit_message:
Include new notification options in sample config

Some new configuration options were added with the change to add
notifications to Keystone, but these new options weren't added
to the sample config file.

This change adds the new options to the sample configuration
file along with the descriptions from
keystone.openstack.common.notifier.api.

Also, if the Keystone server uses the RPC options from
keystone/openstack/common/rpc/__init__.py if using the RPC
notification driver, so these options are also added to the
sample config file.

Having these options in the config file will make it easier for
administrators to update the configuration values.

DocImpact
Change-Id: I85f2450a6fb68d51453adbb5413ad48fe00ca17e

[{'account_id': 6072, 'date': '2013-08-20 08:36:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I have several general concerns about this patch
 1) Obviously it is too big to be reviewed at once
I think it worth splitting into parts at least: lbaas, fwaas
 2) I'd like to see some design docs describing what is implemented.
 3) I'd like to see the reasoning of implementing separate lbaas plugin instead of following current approach of writing plugin-drivers for the current plugin.
While this is not a disallowed way to go, it makes several things harder:
 - maintenance of lbaas service as a whole
 - using lbaas service in multivendor environment. Instead of using additional lbaas provider, admin forced to chose between nvp lbaas and non-nvp lbaas.

 4) patch seems to overlap with another one: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/42811/"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-08-20 08:36:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

Rebase to master as bp/nvp-service-router is updated and merged.'}, {'account_id': 6072, 'date': '2013-09-11 20:14:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(6 inline comments)

A couple of first glance issues"}, {'account_id': 6072, 'date': '2013-09-11 20:36:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: (1 inline comment)

Another general design issue I see here is the current routed service insertion extension, which introduces attribute router_id for VIP, pool and healthmonitor resources.
In my opinion only one resource (pool or VIP?) should have router binding.
Currently, beside checking that router must be 'advanced', you need to check consistency: e.g. you're creating VIP with same router_id as VIP's pool."}, {'account_id': 6072, 'date': '2013-09-11 20:47:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

Also I'd like to see some answers to questions that I've posted to patchset #1.
In Icehouse we're planning major change to loadbalancer data model. A part of that change is M:N vip-pool relationship.
Having additional code relying on loadbalancer db plugin extends the scope of such change.

In other words, I'd prefer if this patch were discussed on the summit first."}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-09-11 23:05:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(17 inline comments)

Even if I am not the author of the patch, I would like to answer Eugene's question as I have been involved in the design of advanced services support for this plugin for the Havana release.

I agree this patch lacks a detailed design document. However, this is not uncommon for patches entirely contained in vendor-specific packages.

Regarding the issues arising from non adoption of the service-driver-agent model, this is a decision for to the Havana release which does not excludes the implementation of a NSX driver for the next releases in order to provide NSX services on NSX and non-NSX networks.

The technical reasons for choosing a different path in Havana are the following:
- unavaiability of a general solution for binding services to a router; I won't repeat this story as the community is unable to find an agreement on the matter. From our side, we just took notice of a disagreement and chose to keep this way of attaching services into the logical topology plugin specific.
- At the data plane level there are some limitations for this release which mean   NSX load balancers and firewalls can be deployed only on NSX fabrics. 

We hope to be able to lift this limitations in the next release, finding smooth and easy solutions for deploying advanced services in Neutron without having to  provide only a choice of a monolitic solution; our team is all for flexibility as well.

I hope this addresses the concern regarding adoption of NSX adv services in multi-vendor environments.

On your concerns for the impact of this on the load balancer service, the only thing I can say is that the plugin model ensures that several distinct implementations of the same API can easily live at the same time.
For instance, if one looks at the existing plugins, you will already find several implementations of db_base_plugin_v2 (base API), l3_db, and securitygroups_db, at least.

If there is a change in the general model, like the one you were mentioning, and this change breaks a particular implementation of that model, it is responsibility of the maintainers of such implementation to fix their code.

Then I would argue that this should not be really a major concern, unless we decide to make adoption of the service - driver - agent model mandatory for code in the main source tree. At the end of the day, it is unlikely a change in a plugin specific package might impact the service's reference implementation; on the other hand changes to the core API and data model made for suiting the needs of a specific plugin (and perhaps even of a specific driver) should be rejected unless reasonable motivation is provided; people who worked on this specific patch ensured that this condition did not verify.


On the code - there are still a few bits to address. I have some more comments in addition to Kaiwei's."}, {'account_id': 6072, 'date': '2013-09-12 04:50:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: No score

(2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 6072, 'date': '2013-09-12 04:53:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: (4 inline comments)

"unavaiability of a general solution for binding services to a router", but still, is it really needed to bind all of three resources (VIP, pool, healthmon) to the router? Why not just one? To me it seems like it could be done the same way as we did for providers.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-09-12 09:49:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

We are reviewing that - see my comments indeed on the patch.
The master resource here will be the pool; I don't think there is need to bind the health monitor to a router; it would probably even be a source of error.

I will work with the dev to assess the need for the vip binding, which is probably not necessary as well."}, {'account_id': 6461, 'date': '2013-09-12 16:50:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Although from the current workflow making pool associate with a router makes sense, I would prefer to make VIP be the one to associate with a router, because VIP is the one that must belong to a router (same VIP cannot be assigned to two or more routers), while a pool can be shared by different VIPs.

Making VIP be the master resource means extra works needs to be done. For example, a pool only needs to be created once on same router no matter how many VIPs on that router use it. A change to a pool means changes to all routers that have VIPs using that pool...'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-09-12 17:43:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Kaiwei,



On whether the association should be on a VIP or a Pool, I think your proposal of binding the VIP makes sense. Also I think this is consistent with the ability of binding of a Pool with multiple VIPs which will be enabled in the next release.

I reckon however that there is agreement on the fact that the association should be performed on one of those two objects, not both.

A side effect of the router binding approach is that, just like Neutron does for floating IPs, it should be ensured that all members of pool are reachable from the VIP via the router. The current LB implementation (I think) assumes it is responsability of the user ensuring members are reachable from the VIP - For havana release this LB implementation can make that assumption too.'}, {'account_id': 6072, 'date': '2013-09-12 20:21:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

I also would like to notice that changing vip-pool relationship to m:n kinda changes the status of pool as 'root' object.
Instead, 'loadbalancer instance' object is proposed that will accumulate vips and pools that are deployed on one backend.
That is something I'd like to discuss on the summit.
It might make sense to bind such object to a router and not vip or pool. Of course while this change is not yet done you may setup binding with what you think is appropriate."}, {'account_id': 7317, 'date': '2013-09-13 10:47:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 7317, 'date': '2013-09-13 10:47:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: (17 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-09-13 11:22:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Works for me

The patch adds advanced service plugin support including
LBaaS/FWaaS for NVP with VCNS

Codes work Done:
    - LBaaS service plugin support both on DB and driver
    - FWaaS service plugin support bot on DB and driver
    - Add Loadbalancer and Firewall objects into routedserviceinsertion to create
    object<->router_id binding
    - VCNS driver LIB API support for service plugin
    - Part of FWaaS plugin unit tests

Tests being done:
    - Verified workflow and datapath of LBaaS/FWaaS plugin

TODO:
    - Complete unit tests
    - Service integration test in real environment

'}, {'created': '2013-09-10 10:15:49.000000000', 'message': 'Support advanced NVP LBaaS Service Plugin

VCNS:
        * NVP LBaaS is an advanced Service of NVP depending on NVP
          advanced service router
            - Once an advanced router id created, one corresponding
              vshield edge will be deployed, and then we can configure
              LB service On the vshield edge
        * NVP LBaaS service plugin still uses LBaaS DB service logic,
          while finally calling vShield Edge to support FWaaS service
            - When one object is created, we will attach the object to
              the advanced router with routedserviceinsertion service
        * on driver part, the driver will first convert the object
          to VSM known object input, and then send a synchronous JSON
          calling to VSM, and receive the result

Implements: blueprint nvp-lbaas-plugin
Change-Id: Iec41f2dc103daddf3bed4d09c147df3865b3dccd

'}, {'created': '2013-09-14 09:39:40.000000000', 'message': 'Support advanced NVP LBaaS Service

The patch adds NVP advanced LBaaS service support for NVP with
VCNS:
        * NVP LBaaS is an advanced Service of NVP depending on NVP
          advanced service router
            - Once an advanced router id created, one corresponding
              vshield edge will be deployed, and then we can configure
              LB service On the vshield edge
        * NVP LBaaS service plugin still uses LBaaS DB service logic,
          while finally calling vShield Edge to support FWaaS service
            - When creating VIP object, service attaches the object to
              the advanced router with routedserviceinsertion service.
              Then before pushing VIP VCNS call, the server would first
              pushing associated POOL VCNS call and associated Monitor
              VCNS call to vShield Edge. Deleting VIP is opposite
              operation
            - Refering to CUD operation of other objects, service would
              first find the associated VIP object and then find the edge bound to
              the router which vip inserted. Then service would push corresponding
              VCNS call to Vshield Edge
        * on driver part, the driver will first convert the object
          to VSM known object input, and then send a synchronous JSON
          calling to VSM, and receive the result

Implements: blueprint nvp-lbaas-plugin
Change-Id: Iec41f2dc103daddf3bed4d09c147df3865b3dccd
'}, {'created': '2013-09-14 09:51:17.000000000', 'message': 'Support advanced NVP LBaaS Service

The patch adds NVP advanced LBaaS service support for NVP with
VCNS:
        * NVP LBaaS is an advanced Service of NVP depending on NVP
          advanced service router
            - Once an advanced router id created, one corresponding
              vshield edge will be deployed, and then we can configure
              LB service On the vshield edge
        * NVP LBaaS service plugin still uses LBaaS DB service logic,
          while finally calling vShield Edge to support FWaaS service
            - When creating VIP object, service attaches the object to
              the advanced router with routedserviceinsertion service.
              Then before pushing VIP VCNS call, the server would first
              pushing associated POOL VCNS call and associated Monitor
              VCNS call to vShield Edge. Deleting VIP is opposite
              operation
            - Refering to CUD operation of other objects, service would
              first find the associated VIP object and then find the edge bound to
              the router which vip inserted. Then service would push corresponding
              VCNS call to Vshield Edge
        * on driver part, the driver will first convert the object
          to VSM known object input, and then send a synchronous JSON
          calling to VSM, and receive the result

Implements: blueprint nvp-lbaas-plugin
Change-Id: Iec41f2dc103daddf3bed4d09c147df3865b3dccd

commit_message:
Support advanced NVP LBaaS Service

The patch adds NVP advanced LBaaS service support for NVP with
VCNS:
        * NVP LBaaS is an advanced Service of NVP depending on NVP
          advanced service router
            - Once an advanced router id created, one corresponding
              vshield edge will be deployed, and then we can configure
              LB service On the vshield edge
        * NVP LBaaS service plugin still uses LBaaS DB service logic,
          while finally calling vShield Edge to support FWaaS service
            - When creating VIP object, service attaches the object to
              the advanced router with routedserviceinsertion service.
              Then before pushing VIP VCNS call, the server would first
              pushing associated POOL VCNS call and associated Monitor
              VCNS call to vShield Edge. Deleting VIP is opposite
              operation
            - Refering to CUD operation of other objects, service would
              first find the associated VIP object and then find the edge bound to
              the router which vip inserted. Then service would push corresponding
              VCNS call to Vshield Edge
        * on driver part, the driver will first convert the object
          to VSM known object input, and then send a synchronous JSON
          calling to VSM, and receive the result

Implements: blueprint nvp-lbaas-plugin
Change-Id: Iec41f2dc103daddf3bed4d09c147df3865b3dccd

[{'created': '2013-08-22 08:30:37.000000000', 'message': 'Support for NVP service plugin

The patch adds advanced FWaaS service plugin support for NVP with
VCNS

    Codes work Done:
        - FWaaS service plugin support both on DB and driver
        - Add Firewall objects into routedserviceinsertion to create
        object<->router_id binding
        - VCNS driver LIB API support for service plugin
        - Part of FWaaS plugin unit tests

    Tests being done:
        - Verified workflow and datapath of FWaaS plugin

    TODO:
        - Complete unit tests
        - Service integration test in real environment

    Implements: blueprint nvp-fwaas-plugin
    Change-Id: Iec41f2dc103daddf3bed4d09c147df3865b3dccd

'}, {'created': '2013-09-13 05:24:51.000000000', 'message': 'Support for NVP advanced FwaaS service

The patch adds advanced FWaaS service support for NVP with
VCNS:
        * NVP FWaaS is an advanced Service of NVP depending on NVP
          advanced service router
            - Once an advanced router id created, one corresponding
              vshield edge will be deployed, and then we can configure
              FW service on the vshield edge
        * NVP FWaaS service plugin still uses FWaaS DB service logic,
          while finally calling vShield Edge to support FWaaS service
            - When one object is created, we will attach the object to
              the advanced router with routedserviceinsertion service
        * on driver part, the driver will first convert the object
          to VSM known object input, and then send a synchronous JSON
          calling to VSM, and receive the result

    Implements: blueprint nvp-fwaas-plugin

Change-Id: Id43af8821f5c553356e3cc870993eef99ef7def3

The patch adds advanced FWaaS service support for NVP with
VCNS:
        * NVP FWaaS is an advanced Service of NVP depending on NVP
          advanced service router
            - Once an advanced router id created, one corresponding
              vshield edge will be deployed, and then we can configure
              FW service on the vshield edge
        * NVP FWaaS service plugin still uses FWaaS DB service logic,
          while finally calling vShield Edge to support FWaaS service
            - When firewall object is created, we will attach the
              object to the advanced router with routedserviceinsertion_db
              service
        * on driver part, the driver will first convert the object
          to VSM known object input, and then send a synchronous JSON
          calling to VSM, and receive the result

commit_message:
Support for NVP advanced FwaaS service

The patch adds advanced FWaaS service support for NVP with
VCNS:
        * NVP FWaaS is an advanced Service of NVP depending on NVP
          advanced service router
            - Once an advanced router id created, one corresponding
              vshield edge will be deployed, and then we can configure
              FW service on the vshield edge
        * NVP FWaaS service plugin still uses FWaaS DB service logic,
          while finally calling vShield Edge to support FWaaS service
            - When firewall object is created, we will attach the
              object to the advanced router with routedserviceinsertion_db
              service
        * on driver part, the driver will first convert the object
          to VSM known object input, and then send a synchronous JSON
          calling to VSM, and receive the result

Implements: blueprint nvp-fwaas-plugin
Change-Id: Id43af8821f5c553356e3cc870993eef99ef7def3

commit_message:
Fix grub/linux text mode override.

Apply a wider range of hammers to the recurring issue of images booting
with graphical consoles.

Change-Id: I96345bf8f2f13d615131557b572201b9d41b6c75

This just adds a sample command line for how to generate the
nova.conf.sample because I keep forgetting how to do it.

commit_message:
Make Instance.Name() not lazy-load things

This fixes Instance.name() to not cause lazy-loads.

Change-Id: I8fe648df8ff0f01d91685446e2b3cf5db1cbfca7
Closes-bug: 1224015

commit_message:
Document ceilometer alarm properties

This adds descriptions to the properties of OS::Ceilometer::Alarm.

Change-Id: I3851c8785c0bd94aae6412e75a02ee98ce13478b
Closes-Bug: #1224162

commit_message:
Use openstack.org git infrastructure for samples.

Updated guides to use the openstack.org git infrastructure for
retrieving sample files from the various OpenStack projects. This
prevents sporadic github outages breaking the guide builds.

Change-Id: Ic637899d2bfa4da1d64b26ef35792d9607458c51

commit_message:
Nova quota content is shared.

Nova quota content is shared between the configuration reference and the
admin user guide. The content has been moved to common and files that
point to it updated.

Change-Id: Iad80f281eb025aa93c773f3eb858e27afb9d0bdc

commit_message:
Make _provision_instances() use Quotas obj

This switches the compute api _provision_instances() method to use the
new world Quotas object.  As a result, restore() needed to be converted
as well.

Related to blueprint unified-object-model

Change-Id: Ia6f6ca47b43348074f3a579e5ab3c7e7b5ce4e38

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-12 18:37:00.000000000', 'message': 'Initialize dependencies in extensions

The contrib extensions should be completely activated by their
inclusion in the pipeline.  However, due to the need to initialize
the managers, there was a direct reference in  a core file to two
extensions.  By delaying the resolution of the dpendencies until
after all pipelies are built, we can remove the references.

Bug 1223524

Change-Id: If9c8d3a1ad13ace45f0240edef58bcb93520687c
'}, {'created': '2013-09-12 18:42:56.000000000', 'message': 'Initialize dependencies in extensions

commit_message:
Initialize dependencies in extensions

The contrib extensions should be completely activated by their
inclusion in the pipeline.  However, due to the need to initialize
the managers, there was a direct reference in  a core file to two
extensions.  By delaying the resolution of the dpendencies until
after all pipelies are built, we can remove the references.

Bug 1223524

Change-Id: If9c8d3a1ad13ace45f0240edef58bcb93520687c

commit_message:
Set NoEcho: true for parameters containing secrets

This prevents secret values being returned for stack-show.

Change-Id: I82eff26fda31511b66c6371f6ded2a5fb559f3fb
Fixes-Bug: #1226730

[{'created': '2013-09-17 22:17:13.000000000', 'message': 'Bump NODE_DISK to 20

I was using NODE_DISK=10 and my undercloud ran out of disk space. This
was with Fedora images, so perhaps they are larger.

Because these are thinly provisioned qcow2 disk images, it seems
worthwhile to be generous rather than cutting it tight.

Change-Id: I9829f9e969e4c3f6e76d78231461a00b1adc6917
'}]
commit_message:
Bump NODE_DISK to 20

I was using NODE_DISK=10 and my undercloud ran out of disk space. This
was with Fedora images, so perhaps they are larger.

Because these are thinly provisioned qcow2 disk images, it seems
worthwhile to be generous rather than cutting it tight.

Change-Id: I9829f9e969e4c3f6e76d78231461a00b1adc6917

commit_message:
Add files to create worker RPM and get api/db/queue/worker nodes deployed.

As part of building out the Barbican network of nodes, this commit adds files
and configuration to create an RPM package for the Barbican worker nodes. Files
needed to make this work as part of a network of Barbican API, queue, worker
and database nodes are also added.

Change-Id: I87a36b7c09bbd3fec7661ce6adbcbb5b0c6df689

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-09 15:16:54.000000000', 'message': "Benchmark tests for Rally

This patch introduces the benchmark test scenarios and the corresponding
tools for their customized launching. 'rally.benchmar.test_scenarios' package
contains some sample tests that shall be used for Nova benchmarking and can
be parameterized using the appropriate test configuration.

The usage of such a test configuration allows to set benchmark parameter values
(which allows to configure, say, the number of compute nodes used in load
testing), as well as to specify the number of times each benchmark should be
launched and whether it should be launched concurrently in several threads.

Test configuration processing is provided by the further development of
TestEngine, which now also can verify the test configuration passed to its
constructor.

The patch also contains some refactoring of the Tester class which makes it
configurable through the test configuration.

Blueprint test-engine
Change-Id: Idd1296537d5a65c0b353ee9812d2e360d3c8ea39

commit_message:
Benchmark test framework for Rally

This patch introduces the benchmark test framework for rally. The presented
framework relies heavily on the usage of test configuration files which allow
to set up which tests should be run in which order and how many times, as well
as parameterize them (e.g., to configure, say, the number of compute nodes used
in load testing). The test configuration also allows to set whether the
benchmark tests should be launched concurrently in several threads.

Test configuration processing is provided by the further development of
TestEngine, which now also can validate the test configuration passed to its
constructor.

The patch also contains some refactoring of the Tester class which makes it
configurable through the test configuration. This functionality is supported
by the TestConfigManager class, another child class of the base ConfigManager
defined in one of the previous patches.

Blueprint test-engine
Change-Id: Idd1296537d5a65c0b353ee9812d2e360d3c8ea39

commit_message:
Add deploy-kexec element

Boots into the new image kernel once baremetal-deploy-helper signals
it is finished using kexec utilities.

Change-Id: I705787cc394ef14200d80404ee497762ab79b452

commit_message:
assertEquals is deprecated, use assertEqual

assertEquals is deprecated in Python 2.7 , need drop it

http://docs.python.org/2/library/unittest.html#deprecated-aliases

Change-Id: I5aeeb3b289e1d29f6338fc9fd47e680909f0a133

commit_message:
Fix misused assertTrue in unit tests

Refactored unit tests to use assertEqual instead of assertTrue
where needed.

Fixes bug #1226374

Change-Id: Ie034536127b13653040e2beaa7247c2ecd13f4f0

commit_message:
Fix hyper-v vhd real size bigger than flavor issue

In hyper-v, after deploy the image, real vhd file size will be
extended from flavor size plus vhd metadata size, this patch
fix this issue by check the vhd type and minus the vhd metadata
size according to the specific vhd type.

Fixes bug #1177927

Change-Id: I51223f4f778f33e73dce1e0f53e23e8d7ac77904

commit_message:
CLI references are shared guides

Move CLI sections to common as they are shared between user guide, admin
user guide, and config reference guide. Update the appendix (which was
already in common) to refer to the new location.

Change-Id: Id51aacea15ce70a90e1a49203665b2797d374e48

commit_message:
Fix apache module 0.9.0 compatibility issue

The `apache` base class should be declared before any subclasses
(like `apache::mod::wsgi`) or defines (like `apache::vhost`)
because the base class does the variable initialization that the
subclasses utilize.

Fixes: bug #1226687

Change-Id: Ia1d694893d8a2e7d38769d2e43076a061e875b54
(cherry picked from commit 9a76675cd40788a8d81ab907da294f9a6698850e)

commit_message:
Register cfg options at module-level

if we register cfg options during SecureMessage.__init__
then we cannot generate nova.conf.sample. So let's move
it to the module-level

Fixes LP# 1222304

Change-Id: I4a132cfabf8f0f6deff5a9bda16584bf9c3e0be8

commit_message:
Fix apache module 0.9.0 compatibility issue

The `apache` base class should be declared before any subclasses
(like `apache::mod::wsgi`) or defines (like `apache::vhost`)
because the base class does the variable initialization that the
subclasses utilize.

Fixes: bug #1226687

Change-Id: Ia1d694893d8a2e7d38769d2e43076a061e875b54

commit_message:
Change the duplicate class name TestDictMatches in test_matches.py

There are two classes with the same name 'TestDictMatches' ,let's change one to
TestIsSubDictOf.

Change-Id: I1f1059054070228265bca74cb8aaad2c8d3f8812

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-16 23:36:02.000000000', 'message': "Fix error raised when router-interface-delete on no-snat routers

Previously, a 500 error would be raised trying to remove a subnet
from a no-snat router because we were trying to remove the snat
rules that didn't exist in the router.

Fixes bug: 1226323

Change-Id: Ieff0ed4bdbac39ac07e597753272a4f5d40cb346
"}]
commit_message:
Fix error raised when router-interface-delete on no-snat routers

Previously, a 500 error would be raised trying to remove a subnet
from a no-snat router because we were trying to remove the snat
rules that didn't exist in the router.

Fixes bug: 1226323

Change-Id: Ieff0ed4bdbac39ac07e597753272a4f5d40cb346

commit_message:
Fix console api pass tuple as topic to console rpc api

The topic should be string, not a tuple

Fix bug 1221541

Change-Id: I4bbb9bdeb5108436fe76db69f1546ac2bd0c7a40

commit_message:
Fix the order of query output for postgres

Sorts the query results and dictionary of expected results by two columns
rather than one which isn't unqiue.

Fixes bug 1208701

Change-Id: Icd21a008f7736a4d9027effb0633a506aae0f602

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-13 01:50:04.000000000', 'message': 'Remove -local from User Guide PDF file

The User Guide is build for trunk only and the Jenkins job does not
set currently the release.path.name variable. Thus, the published
PDF file is called user-guide-local.pdf. Even with a changed
Jenkins job, this would be wrong, it should just be user-guide.pdf.

Change-Id: I9b9b0affadde2d483e4778322470d6a9e8db3cf1
'}]
commit_message:
Remove -local from User Guide PDF file

The User Guide is build for trunk only and the Jenkins job does not
set currently the release.path.name variable. Thus, the published
PDF file is called user-guide-local.pdf. Even with a changed
Jenkins job, this would be wrong, it should just be user-guide.pdf.

Change-Id: I9b9b0affadde2d483e4778322470d6a9e8db3cf1

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-18 19:08:20.000000000', 'message': 'nova-compute crashes if VC not available.

The ESX driver gets a connection to vCenter Server on startup.  If VC is not available, nova-compute crashes.  This adds slow retry to which will fix the start up use cases of nova-compute starting before VC.  The errors are logged in case the issue is a mis-confiugration of VC

Change-Id: I0801ab4a4e4bf32b8119e131a45a2fdb7884a4fd
Fixes: bug #1192016

Change-Id: I0801ab4a4e4bf32b8119e131a45a2fdb7884a4fd
'}]
commit_message:
VMware: nova-compute crashes if VC not available

The ESX driver gets a connection to vCenter Server on startup.
Currently, if vCenter Server is not available, nova-compute crashes.
This fix adds slow retry when nova-compute starts before vCenter
Server is available.  The errors are logged in case the issue is
a mis-confiugration of vCenter Server

Fixes: bug #1192016

Change-Id: I0801ab4a4e4bf32b8119e131a45a2fdb7884a4fd

commit_message:
Patched Orchestration wadl: orchestration-api.wadl

Corrected title and description for method template_validate.
Standardized use of title capitalization in method titles as in other OS wadls.
Fixed description for method Get Resource Metadata.
Updated pom.xml file to use doctools version 1.9.3 instead of 1.9.1 to correct line breaks.

Change-Id: I7aacd26dd0bac745a496bc90f3613b560524f3a6

This patch also introduces a base class to test proxy.

commit_message:
Fix doc. pointing to correct binary

The binary installed and called to clear all OpenStack databases
is reset-db and not wipe-openstack

Change-Id: I77153381964342761d8cced4ac617419a3008c01

commit_message:
feat: define interfaces for proxy storage

This patchset introduces an interface for future proxy storage drivers
to work with. Along with the interface, the basic machinery for
writing unit tests for the storage drivers is exposed.

It introduces two controllers:
- PartitionsController
- CatalogueController

This should facilitate exposing stevedore entry points for defining
custom proxy storage drivers.

Appropriate exception classes are also exposed.

six is introduced as a dependency to take advantage of
six.add_metaclass.

commit_message:
feat: marconi-proxy forwarding

This patchset inttroduces forwarding. The following resources are now
passed on to marconi:
- claim-related requests
- message-related requests
- queue stats requests

Furthermore, on queue metadata operations, the queue catalogue is now
updated with the desired metadata.

Change-Id: I16fa20bc53523574b7e8c2e30556ed6ad7df5a76
Implements: blueprint placement-service

commit_message:
Add Docker to Hypervisors section

Docker is an open-source engine which automates the deployment of
applications as highly portable, self-sufficient containers which
are independent of hardware, language, framework, packaging system
and hosting provider.

Support for Docker has been added in Havana.

This patch adds the a section on Docker to the Hypervisors
section of the Configuration Reference. It requires the config table
found in this patch: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/45922/
before merging.

Change-Id: If89225036cccad9cc2c8eb3ce7cc3bf6bd710cf0
Closes-Bug: 1221207

commit_message:
delete a non existent flavor extra spec returns 204

Attempting to delete a non existent flavor extra spec returns
204 instead of 404, the fix was return 404 for such case.

Fix bug 1219445

Change-Id: I61db53486b5696fe74f16ac2d98971092137fadf

commit_message:
Add delete method to Flavor class

In tempest, some tests use delete() method of each resource class
(Server, SecurityGroup, etc.) for cleaning up when each test finishes.
Now we are adding some tests, which create a Flavor instance, to tempest
and we need the delete() method of Flavor class.

Fixes bug #1218156

Change-Id: I210d62aa45510858346315046cf57ea7b1de7b7b

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-02 06:33:40.000000000', 'message': 'Allow name argument to flavor-access-add

Administrator cannot use the flavor name in arguments of
"nova flavor-access-add" and "nova flavor-access-remove".

This patch fixes this problem.

Change-Id: I68b267dc071382f1978efc2088cd8e837455e8b4
Related-Bug: #1205298
'}, {'created': '2013-09-02 17:23:27.000000000', 'message': 'Allow name argument to flavor-access-add

Administrator cannot use the flavor name in arguments of
"nova flavor-access-add" and "nova flavor-access-remove".

This patch fixes this problem.

commit_message:
Allow name argument to flavor-access-add

Administrator cannot use the flavor name in arguments of
"nova flavor-access-add" and "nova flavor-access-remove".

This patch fixes this problem.

Change-Id: I68b267dc071382f1978efc2088cd8e837455e8b4
Related-Bug: #1205298

commit_message:
python3: Fix Traceback while running unit tests

Python3 uses the the concepts of text and (binary) data
instead of Unicode strings and 8-bit strings. In python3
all text is unicode; however encoded unicode is represented
as binary data.

Use the six module to use six.binary_types and six.text_types
where apporiate:
- six.text_type unicode() in python2 and str in python3.
- six.basestring() in python2 and str in python3.

blueprint python3-novaclient

Change-Id: Ie7b393abe6beac22eaf127b7fc7bbc372c338211
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
python3: Compatibility for iteritems differences

In python3 dict.iteritems(), dict.iterkeys(), and
dict.itervalues() are no longer supported. So use
six.iteritems() where it is appropriate.

blueprint python3-novaclient

Change-Id: I8c39bfe426d08d36215b55c3245dcfc69ec72517
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

[{'created': '2013-09-07 16:52:39.000000000', 'message': "python3: Fix traceback while running unit tests

While running unit tests with python3, we get the following traceback:

TypeError: 'map' object is not subscriptable

In python3, a map returns an iterable object of type map,
and is not subscriptable.

Refactor to not use indicies so that it is python2 and python3
compat.

Change-Id: Iaf0de19f08fa3e91ee79c174ccc86a8bbe4acdc8
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

In python3, a map returns an iterable object of type map,
and is not subscriptable.

Refactor to not use indicies so that it is python2 and python3

blueprint python3-novaclient

Change-Id: Iaf0de19f08fa3e91ee79c174ccc86a8bbe4acdc8
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>
"}]
commit_message:
python3: Fix traceback while running unit tests

While running unit tests with python3, we get the following traceback:

TypeError: 'map' object is not subscriptable

In python3, a map returns an iterable object of type map,
and is not subscriptable.

Refactor to not use indicies so that it is python2 and python3
compat.

blueprint python3-novaclient

Change-Id: Iaf0de19f08fa3e91ee79c174ccc86a8bbe4acdc8
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

The OpenStack native OS::Nova::Server gives us the full list of
networks rather than AWS::EC2::Instance's contrived view of 'private'
and 'public'. We know we want ctlplane, and use Fn::Select to choose
that network directly. The outer Fn::Select is meant to choose the

commit_message:
Replace broken usage of first_private_address

The OpenStack native OS::Nova::Server gives us the full list of
networks rather than AWS::EC2::Instance's contrived view of 'private'
and 'public'. We know we want ctlplane, and use Fn::Select to choose
that network directly. The outer Fn::Select is meant to choose the
first network every time, which may not always be correct, but is at
this point.

Change-Id: Iae54ab8d9ac8d84f4f6e2f86ac1b66aacb687473

commit_message:
feat: marconi proxy (v1, health)

Adds handling for the following endpoints:
- GET /v1
- GET /v1/health

It simply forwards the requests to the first available partition.

Change-Id: I990cce0faddf2afc864357ccb6a3cb08c6aca6a1
Implements: blueprint placement-service

commit_message:
Fix os.getlogin() problem with no tty

Catch OSError(s) from  os.getlogin() and fall back to looking at
environment variables to figure out the user's name. The OSError
is thrown where there is no tty for the python process when
os.getlogin() is called.

Fixes LP: 1221491

Change-Id: Id6634921cdf0deb77cf32a5b9101ec475946aa81

(10 inline comments)

Great work Alejandro.

I added some comments.

I'm also wondering how this could benefit from Keystone's services API. Would it be fair to get a list of marconi partitions (keystone services) from there and populate the cache? What about having a keystone backend for the proxy?

While reading the code it seemed to me that we're replicating some functionality so, I'm now trying to figuer out how / if we can take advantage of some of keystones features."}, {'account_id': 6944, 'date': '2013-09-13 16:34:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17: (8 inline comments)

Thanks for the awesome review, Flavio! I'll be taking many of those ideas and updating the patch with them."}, {'account_id': 6944, 'date': '2013-09-13 20:38:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: (1 inline comment)

- rely on Falcon's body_encoded mechanism instead of explicitly encoding reponses
- ensure_ascii on all json.dumps
- TODO comment noting version in routes"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-09-17 15:06:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18: Works for me

This patchset introduces the marconi-proxy service. The service makes
it possible to abstract marconi deployments into partitions, as

commit_message:
feat: marconi proxy

This patchset introduces the marconi-proxy service. The service makes
it possible to abstract marconi deployments into partitions, as
defined in the referenced blue print.

This reference implementation uses falcon to manage WSGI aspects,
redis for catalogue storage, and recommends gunicorn or uwsgi as the
server.

Includes:
- registering partitions
- cataloguing queues
- forwarding requests to the appropriate marconi partitions
- round-robin selection of partition nodes
- weighted selection of partitions at queue creation time
- queue listing w/ metadata (GET /v1/queues?detailed=true)

Still needed, working on:
- unit tests

A few things that will be handled in later patchsets
- queue metadata handling + metadata endpoint (2)
- request forwarding to marconi (3)
- hierarchical caching with authoritative persistent storage (4)
- regeneration of the catalogue from authoritative cache (5)

Change-Id: I5dabc92497f3edf5bc32d58c8a2c4e43ff9833a3
Implements: blueprint placement-service

commit_message:
Rename ipmi driver to ipmitool

To make naming more consistent with other ipmi drivers that
will be introduced later, the module name for ipmi driver
that uses the ipmitool is renamed from ipmi to ipmitool.

Change-Id: I8ec0d4beb29a06af7b27d3ff0620fab5446579b1

commit_message:
Public API

Some parts of the API should be available without
supplying an authentication token, e.g., / - the root
and /v1 - the specification of the API v1.

This patch allows to specify public routes in the
Pecan application configuration file and specifies the
mentioned routes as public ones.

Fixes: bug #1221263

Change-Id: Ie106f0767158d30fd89a72f011748537435ddeef

commit_message:
Modify --num-instances flag description to clarify limit upper bound

Closes Bug:#1220703

Modified --num-instances flag description in shell.py to clarify that
number of instances spawned are limited by the quota.

Change-Id: I29fa175f310ab1e073dca5f453a3540dcdde933d
Signed-off-by: Abhishek Lahiri <aviostack@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-13 16:34:49.000000000', 'message': 'Add a block device for the image when using BDMv2

Right now the cli was already adding a block device when it was passed
an image_id to boot from and more than one block device mapping v2. This
is done because nova expects the image to be another block device
mapping and would ignore it otherwise.

This patch moves this functionality from the cli to the base module so
users of the module can benefit from this and also to prevent some
misunderstandings that may arise when using BDMv2 and the image gets
ignored by nova. In the future we should handle this in the nova side
assuming a new BDM when an image is provided.

Fixes bug #1225061

Change-Id: I29f31c24f958cfa8b68b33edc63e0d7031aa241f
'}]
commit_message:
Add a block device for the image when using BDMv2

Right now the cli was already adding a block device when it was passed
an image_id to boot from and more than one block device mapping v2. This
is done because nova expects the image to be another block device
mapping and would ignore it otherwise.

This patch moves this functionality from the cli to the base module so
users of the module can benefit from this and also to prevent some
misunderstandings that may arise when using BDMv2 and the image gets
ignored by nova. In the future we should handle this in the nova side
assuming a new BDM when an image is provided.

Fixes bug #1225061

Change-Id: I29f31c24f958cfa8b68b33edc63e0d7031aa241f

commit_message:
Role name should not be translated in Project Member Edit Tab

Role names are retrieved from keystone and they should be displayed
as-is. The same thing applies to UpdateProjectGroupsAction.

Change-Id: Ieea7ba58cff66c506a7e7f26f26341fe5afd01b1
Closes-Bug: #1226510

commit_message:
Fix changes_since for V3 API

The V3 API changed the changes-since parameter to changes_since
for consistency with other parameters. However, the db level
expects changes-since as the filter. So this change transforms
changes_since to changes-since before passing it to the compute
layer.

Closes-Bug: 1220045

Change-Id: Id34ffe8aa75b20d11dcb1b4a9ba36e2586dae1e3

commit_message:
Make Instance.save() log missing save handlers

Also, fix the name of the _save_fault() handler to be what it should
be, which is what triggered the ungraceful handling of this bug in
the first place.

Change-Id: I160f42b130810134135d2a22198fc0b66a7af585
Closes-bug: 1223957

Hi Kevin, thanks for reviewing.

> couldn't a consistent-ordering property be done by using sorted() in utils.print_dict()? Would that be sufficient?

If using sorted(), that is in alphabetical orders. "nova quota-show" with current this patch prints quotas in importance orders(instances, cores, ram, ..).

commit_message:
Fix the print order of quota-show

Current "nova qouta-show" prints quotas by random order like the
following:

 $ nova quota-show
 +-----------------------------+-------+
 | Property                    | Value |
 +-----------------------------+-------+
 | metadata_items              | 128   |
 | injected_file_content_bytes | 10240 |
 | ram                         | 51200 |
 | floating_ips                | 10    |
 | key_pairs                   | 100   |
 | instances                   | 10    |
 | security_group_rules        | 20    |
 | injected_files              | 5     |
 | cores                       | 20    |
 | fixed_ips                   | -1    |
 | injected_file_path_bytes    | 255   |
 | security_groups             | 10    |
 +-----------------------------+-------+
 $

This patch fixes its order for fitting to the option order of
"nova quota-update" like the following:

 $ nova quota-show
 +-----------------------------+-------+
 | Quota                       | Limit |
 +-----------------------------+-------+
 | instances                   | 10    |
 | cores                       | 20    |
 | ram                         | 51200 |
 | floating_ips                | 10    |
 | fixed_ips                   | -1    |
 | metadata_items              | 128   |
 | injected_files              | 5     |
 | injected_file_content_bytes | 10240 |
 | injected_file_path_bytes    | 255   |
 | key_pairs                   | 100   |
 | security_groups             | 10    |
 | security_group_rules        | 20    |
 +-----------------------------+-------+

Fixes bug #1223233

Change-Id: I482fd26b9114ac718dc4a16753e7692213bd3690

commit_message:
Small bugfix for client v3

Client.__init__ method used self.os_cache variable in an internal method call
though this variable had not been initialized earlier.
In addition, unittests added for full coverage of client v3.

Change-Id: I421f82932b65f137932d933e04d42064bec0d08d

commit_message:
Use test.TestingException where possible

Instead of calling 'raise Exception()' in a stub, use
tests.TestingException and only catch that exception.  This will make
sure the test have less false positives and hide other exceptions.

Change-Id: I384c93e220d570abec25dcbacead0aa3bc33cbcf
Partial-Bug: #1223605

commit_message:
Ignore junk os-config-applier templates.

Moustache can't render binary files, and open editor sessions can
create such things which were being copied into the built tree.

Change-Id: Ie1c5861e89af5f6aa2202800accd7e2099c953ec
Closes-Bug: #1224728

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-09-16 21:44:22.000000000', 'message': 'Remove all use of and references to bm_poseur.

Complete the migration away from bm_poseur by replacing its final use
(get-macs) with our own script for fetching MAC addresses of nodes.

get-vm-mac extends the previous functionality by matching multiple
nodes instead of a single node and by waiting for the required number of
nodes to be defined in libvirt.

This migration is desirable to remove a non-openstack code dependency
and also to enable devtest.sh to collect MAC addresses during an
automated run.

Change-Id: Ied1ce9d785f08f2e4dec2fdad3a99248c9654777
'}, {'created': '2013-09-16 21:52:57.000000000', 'message': 'Remove all use of and references to bm_poseur.

and also to enable devtest.sh to collect MAC addresses during an
automated run.

commit_message:
Remove all use of and references to bm_poseur.

Complete the migration away from bm_poseur by replacing its final use
(get-macs) with a script (get-vm-mac). Remove a step from devtest.md by
calling get-vm-mac from create-nodes.

Dan, why doesn't this cover all of the virt drivers?  I see this in the vmware driver:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/virt/vmwareapi/driver.py#L320

hyper-v:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/virt/hyperv/hostops.py#L128

docker:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/virt/docker/driver.py#L134

Looks like baremetal uses the system uuid so that shouldn't change."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-09-16 16:01:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

I didn't add hyperv or vmware because I needed to spend more time understanding the potential effects of how they manage multiple systems from a single compute instance. We could add those guys in here, or I could tweak the commit message to exclude them for now."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2013-09-16 16:06:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

xen looks good after the clarification, otherwise I'd move the powervm test case into the existing method and yeah, we should probably have a note in the commit message that this is only for a subset of all of the virt drivers unless you want to use this patch to tackle the others pointed out."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-09-16 16:36:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2013-09-16 16:42:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)
